title: 114_hr5215
content: The Act may be cited as the "Closing the Meal Gap Act of 2016" and includes amendments. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to define a 'low-cost food plan' for a family of four, determining uniform allotments for all households based on this diet. The Secretary is required to make adjustments to the cost of food plans for different regions and household sizes, taking into account economies of scale and reflecting the cost of food in specific states. Adjustments are made annually to reflect the cost of the diet in the preceding June. In section 8(a) and section 16(c)(1)(A)(ii), changes are made to replace "thrifty food plan" with "low-cost food plan" and increase the percentage from 8 to 10. Additionally, adjustments are made in section 16(c)(1)(A)(ii) for fiscal year 2017, with a maximum amount of $50. In section 19(a)(2)(A) of the U.S.C. 2028, changes are made for fiscal years 2004 through 2016, with specific funding amounts allocated for fiscal years 2017 and beyond, subject to appropriations under section 18(a). The standard medical expense deduction under the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include a deduction for actual medical expenses incurred by elderly or disabled members, excluding special diets. The standard medical expense deduction under the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to be $140 for fiscal year 2017, with adjustments based on the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers: Medical Care. State agencies may establish a greater deduction that meets cost neutrality standards. Additionally, the cap on excess shelter expenses is eliminated. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to change subparagraphs and work requirements. Funding for employment and training programs is also adjusted. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to update sections related to subparagraphs and work requirements. Funding for employment and training programs is also revised. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to update sections related to subparagraphs and work requirements, as well as funding for employment and training programs. Additionally, amendments are made to various sections of the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Act of 1981. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to make technical corrections, updating sections related to subparagraphs and work requirements. Amendments are also made to various sections of the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Act of 1981. The Act and its amendments will be effective on October 1, 2016, except for certain certification periods starting before that date.
